bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. SENSENBRENNER:H.R. 727.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:The authority to enact this bill is derived from, but maynot be limited to, Article I, Section 8, Clause 18, andArticle III, Section 1 of the United States Constitution.[Page H924]

item.name: Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet Subcommittee

item.title: Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2011

latestAction.text: Read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

item.name: Courts, Intellectual Property, and the Internet Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Courts, Commercial and Administrative Law.
Referred to the House Committee on the Judiciary.

item.name: Government ethics and transparency, public corruption

summary.text:
Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2011 - Amends the federal judicial code to establish the Office of Inspector General for the Judicial Branch of the U.S. government, to be headed by an Inspector General appointed by the Chief Justice. Sets a term of four years, which may be extended by additional reappointments. Authorizes the Chief Justice to remove an Inspector General from office.

Requires the Office, except with respect to the Supreme Court, to: (1) conduct investigations of alleged misconduct in the Judicial Branch; (2) conduct and supervise audits and investigations; and (3) prevent and detect waste, fraud, and abuse.

Provides for whistleblower protection.

bill.title: Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2011

item.title: Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2011
To amend title 28, United States Code, to provide an Inspector General for the judicial branch, and for other purposes.
Judicial Transparency and Ethics Enhancement Act of 2011

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Courts, Commercial and Administrative Law.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
